summary: Next Generation Military Integrated Modular Avionics
content: Next Generation Military Integrated Modular Avionics

objective:
In the foreseeable future, a new generation of military aerial platforms demands advanced avionics supporting innovative architectures, enhanced functionalities, and heightened performance, safety, and cyber resilience. Operating through a system-of-systems approach, these platforms need increased data sharing and processing, alongside specific requirements for development cycles and defense-related missions. 

The specific objective of this proposal is to study, design and demonstrate, within a 36-months timeframe, key components for the next generation of modular avionics, including:

- Identification of needs related to next generation military integrated modular avionics which will be used by legacy and next generation aerial platforms. 
- Study and identification of new high level architecture principles that should consider the need of multi-domain operations (from a safety perspective) and multi-level security.
- Identification, study and proof of concept of key technologies which must support possible future architecture solutions considering multiple constraints.
- Design of NG-MIMA scalable reference architecture(s) to be instantiated on different platforms.

NG-MIMA aims to revolutionize military avionics by bringing a new era of integrated modular avionics carefully tailored to address the distinctive and evolving requirements of military airborne platforms. Pioneering a novel European-scale design, the consortium emphasizes collaboration, harmonization, and integration with other initiatives (such as EICACS (EDF-2021-AIR-D-CAC)). The resulting NG-MIMA architecture and technologies will pave the foundation for future actions such as a full demonstrator or even the seed of a future European standard. Led by INDRA, the well-balance consortium comprises 26 entities from 10 EU Member States. NG-MIMA is poised to significantly contribute to European sovereignty and nurturing a robust ecosystem for military integrated modular avionics in defense.
projectObjective:
In the foreseeable future, a new generation of military aerial platforms demands advanced avionics supporting innovative architectures, enhanced functionalities, and heightened performance, safety, and cyber resilience. Operating through a system-of-systems approach, these platforms need increased data sharing and processing, alongside specific requirements for development cycles and defense-related missions. 

The specific objective of this proposal is to study, design and demonstrate, within a 36-months timeframe, key components for the next generation of modular avionics, including:

- Identification of needs related to next generation military integrated modular avionics which will be used by legacy and next generation aerial platforms. 
- Study and identification of new high level architecture principles that should consider the need of multi-domain operations (from a safety perspective) and multi-level security.
- Identification, study and proof of concept of key technologies which must support possible future architecture solutions considering multiple constraints.
- Design of NG-MIMA scalable reference architecture(s) to be instantiated on different platforms.

NG-MIMA aims to revolutionize military avionics by bringing a new era of integrated modular avionics carefully tailored to address the distinctive and evolving requirements of military airborne platforms. Pioneering a novel European-scale design, the consortium emphasizes collaboration, harmonization, and integration with other initiatives (such as EICACS (EDF-2021-AIR-D-CAC)). The resulting NG-MIMA architecture and technologies will pave the foundation for future actions such as a full demonstrator or even the seed of a future European standard. Led by INDRA, the well-balance consortium comprises 26 entities from 10 EU Member States. NG-MIMA is poised to significantly contribute to European sovereignty and nurturing a robust ecosystem for military integrated modular avionics in defense.
title: Next Generation Military Integrated Modular Avionics

summary: New European WarHEAd Technologies
content: New European WarHEAd Technologies

projectObjective:
The New European WarHEAd Technologies (NEWHEAT) project aims to find solutions to defeat most recent and foreseeable threats that will emerge in the near future to the armed forces of EU Member States. At the ground combat level, major threats are modern main battle tanks that apply active protection systems and improved explosive reactive armour, as well as infrastructures that integrate high-performance concrete. 

These threats will become even more challenging: besides Russia, China will soon possess similar systems, which will also become more present in North Africa and the Middle East in the coming years. 

New warhead technologies are a must-have for the armed forces of EU Member States to keep their lead and defeat these threats. NEWHEAT aims to improve the performance of conventional shaped charge by integrating new high explosive, new liner materials and new geometries. To go beyond the State-of-the-Art and address future challenges, NEWHEAT will also focus on the development of new concepts and demonstrators for warheads: 
- Explosively Formed Projectiles 
- Multi-Liner Explosively Formed Projectiles 
- Slow Stretching Jet Shaped Charges

NEWHEAT will gather the background and know-how of 8 partners and 5 subcontractors (including one SME, one mid-cap, 5 large companies and 6 RTO) from 7 countries to develop, design and test these new concepts. This ambitious research project, implemented over 36 months, represents an unprecedented opportunity for the partners to enforce cross-border cooperation and pave the way for new cooperation, development actions, and industrialization after the end of the project. While keeping their technical superiority, EU armed forces will also improve their autonomy: the NEWHEAT consortium covers all the knowledge, technical requirements, and capacities to develop, test and even produce at an industrial scale these future warheads.
